div1.head: Notes on the Williamson manuscript, by Henry Rose Carter, [1924]
div1.p: To accompany MSS on “The Use of Fish for Mosquito Control”
/LC

Page 1: (1)-- As expressed: “it is thought,” this is correct, but it
is becoming less and less held as observations increase.

Page 1: (2)-- The time limit of the infectivity of man to Stegomyia
is not certainly established as being 3 days: (See Noguchi and Carter):
Might insert “about” before “the first three days.”

Page 1: (3)-- This is very true. The evidence to the contrary is
necessarily negative and is, I think, of not sufficient mass to be con-
vincing.

Page 1: (4)-- Absolutely true and good. This meets the opposition of
McGregor and a number of British (and some French) medical entomologists.

Page 2: (5)--All the arguments, that I have seen, against the use of fish
have been against their use in Anopheles control and your own argument,
on the previous page, is for fish in Anopheles control. Why then quote
Connor who has used them solely in Stegomyia control, in which the prob-
lem is absolutely different from that of control of Anopheles by fish?

Page 2: (6)--Some species of Aedes (as in Saskatchewan: Minnesota
etc.) oviposit far from water, but in depressions in the earth, which
will be filled with water (from melting snow) in the early summer in
which their eggs hatch. This is of no importance as the mosquitoes
with which we are concerned, lay eggs either on water or at the water's
edge.

Page 2: (7)--I think that only the eggs of Anopheles have these
“floaters.”

Page 2: (8)-- This is, I think, true of a number--probably of all--
of the genus Aedes. Bacot has hatched eggs of Stegomyia after more than
eight months drying.
drying.

Page 2: (9)--This is most true. Yet later on page 2 (12) surface feeding
fish are specially recommended for containers i,e, for the control of aegypt
feeding the larvae of which mosquito is a bottom species

Page 2: (10)-- Small trash floating in masses, we have called it
“floatage.” is as bad as aqueous vegetation. In my experience, the alga
Spirogyra, binding floatage, or delicate floating vegetation (like Vallisneria
lerina spiralis) together, or sometimes even by itself, is of all things
the most efficient protection for Anopheles larvae against fish.

Page 2: (11)-- This is most true--only in the U. S. we have no Ano-
pheles which breeds in the swift part (the ripple) of a stream. The A.
maculatus (the old Wilmori) in the Malay States breeds in swift water.
We have found no fish suitable to control stream-breeding in the U. S.

Page 2: (12)-- Why a “surface feeder”? If used for Anopheles control,
as in the underground cisterns and wells in Palestine, yes: But the use of
fish in containers is especially for Stegomyia control. This is not a sur-
face larva, like Anopheles, and a bottom-feeding fish would theoretically
be the best. Certainly the fish named by Connor (the “Mojarra”) (Page 7 (X)):
Caldwett. p 7 (X) M.SS Hanson (the “Life”) and Houle (the “Chalaco” and others) as being especial-
ly suitable have been bottom-feeders. LePrince (Page 7. (L.P) a line selected a top
feeder “as likely to give the best results”

Bottom-feeding fish too, are less apt to be dipped out of the contain-
er or injured by the vessel used to dip water from it than those living on the
top of the water. They are less affected by change of temperature (See
Page 7 MSS). They would also be less snesitive to the absence of
light--as was found to be the case at Merida (See Page 8 MSS).

Page 2: (13)-- In some places sunfish are the only kind possible, as
the game fish eat all kind not protected by spines & these to some although a less-extent. Except “Pumpkin Seed,”
however, they have, in my experience, been failures, as the others draw
too much water and hence do not go into the shallows or among weeds and
weeds and
-3-
floatage.

Page 3: (X)--I applied to the Bureau of Fisheries in 1914 for Gambusia,
or other larviporous fish, for use in the Pool of Lock No. 12, Coosa River,
Alabama. They had none and stated that there was no appropriation for
hatcheries for any save game fish. The need of hatcheries whence such
fish could be procured was taken up by a number of prominent business men,
interested in such pools, in Alabama: Georgia and North Carolina and in
1915 I was notified that such hatcheries were started at Edenton, N. C.
and Palestine, Texas.

Page 5: (14)-- In the large bodies of water impounded for power,
collections of floating trash (what we have called “floatage”), especially
if associated with the alga Spirogyra, have been found more efficient in
protecting Anopheles larvae than vegetation. Certainly in recent ponds.
Larvae have not been found in other kinds of algae and only with Spirogyra
when it is alive. Some kind of alga--a dense blue-green plant--has at
times so completely covered the water--like a blanket--that no larvae
could live on, or in, it. No larvae are found in recently dead or dying algae.
Page 5: (Y)-- This man's name is Parker, not Park.

Page 7: (15) and Page 8: (16)-- Soap--a solution of soft soap in al-
chohol--proved 100% efficacious in Peru (Piura and Paita) and either Con-
nor or Scannell reported the same from Mexico last spring. Laundresses
like this to be added. They forget to replace copper only too often;
(Scannell or Connor). Soap-powder would do as well as the solution.

Page 8: (17)-- Hanson says that his favorite, the “Life,” feeds at
the bottom during the day and on the surface at night. May fear light.

Page 8: (18)-- Have seen Gambusia, in the U. S., eat Anopheles lar-
vae within 12 hours of birth by Ceasarian section.

Page 8: (19)-- “Chata” is said to both a top and bottom-feeder--like
like
-4-
Hanson's “life.” “Chalaco” is a bottom-feeder.

Page 9: (20)-- Were Stegomyia breeding in these streams and ditches?
Connor told me he confined his work to water in artificial containers, as
he found Stegomyia larvae nowhere else.

Page 10: (21)--Fish were not used in Cuba in the first campaign a-
gainst Stegomyia (1901), but they were so used there tentatively, in
that of 1905 and intensively, by McMillan, in 1908 in Camaguey.
Page 10: (22)-- Absolutely true wherever proper fish are available.

Page 11: (23)-- The Life, especially favored of Hanson, is a species
of cat-fish (Eigenmann).

Page 11: (24)--Of all vegetation in the U. S., the alga Spirogyra is,
in my experience, the worst. In no other kind of alga have I ever found
Anopheles larvae. “Floatage” (i. e. small trash floating in masses) is
as bad as vegetation. When vegetation hanging over--or floating on or
just under--the surface of the water, is covered with fine floatage and
bound together with spirogyra, it is the worst possible--as was the case
at Quantico, Va., in 1917 & '18, with Vallisneria spiralis (wild celery)
for the vegetation.

Gambusia will, however, work their way in among both vegetation and
floatage to a considerable extent and even into clumps of Spirogyra, if
they are loose enough. They even occasionally have jumped into the boat-
like lotus pads holding water. The above combination of vegetation:
floatage and alga, however, was too much for them.

Page 12: (25)-- Considering how close Barbadoes is to Trinidad and the
Main, it would seem perfectly possible that Anopheles imagos might be in-
troduced by vessel, but this genus, unlike Stegomyia and C. fatigans,
is not much of a sea-farer. It had not been found in Hawaii up to 1912.

Page 12: (26)-- It is worth noting that there being no Anopheles in
Hawaii, the fish control is used only against Stegomyia and some species of
of
-5-
Culex--especially quinquefasciatus (fatigans).

Page 13: (27)-- How can one clear a swamp of vegetation and debris
without converting it into something else than a swamp? Many fish (as
Gambusia affinis, in the U. S.) will give a good percentage of control--
not 100%, however, in the presence of considerable vegetation, if there
be enough of them.

Page 15: (27 1/2)-- This is common of the half-dead lotus leaves
around Quantico, Va., and Plymouth, N. C. They float high and are like
boats. They hold water on their upper surface, hence give perfect protect-
ion to larvae in such water: yet they occasionally hold Gambusia, which
must have jumped in.

Page 16: (28)-- There are laws in Italy against the culture of rice
withing certain distances of a town or village: the distance varying as
the size of the town up to a certain limit (Celli).

The same has been true in South Spain from the Xlllth. Century--the
limit being three miles from the centre of the plaza. This, however--
a decree of Don Martin of Aragon--was from a religious motive--“only the
Infidels ate this malificent grain.” (Villalba)

Page 17: (28')-- This paper of Dubois was extremely interesting, but
elvers (as young eels are called) are rarely seen in this hemisphere in
sufficient numbers for use and, very obviously, they cannot be bred arti-
ficially. I judge that their use is confined to Western Europe.

Page 19: (29)--This is true for Anopheles control. The fish most
suitable for Stegomyia control (i. e. for water in containers) in the
U. S. has not been worked out. I think, however, that Gambusia affinis
or Fundulus notatus--the latter an extremely tough fish--would do fairly
well, although both are top-feeders and probably a better (bottom-feeder)
could be found.

Nor have we yet found found a satisfactory fish--for the control
control
-6-
of Anopheles in fairly swift streams in the U. S.

Page 20: (30)-- In the large bodies of water, impounded for power or
for improvement of navigation, some of which cover from 6,000 to 10,000
acres, top-minnows have been found extremely efficient in preventing the
production of Anopheles, when proper measures have been taken to enable
them to have access to such larvae. This is done most practically by oc-
casionally lowering the pond so as to leave all floatage etc. stranded on
the bank above water--so that a clean water's edge, with no protection
for larvae, is presented to the fish. A high percentage of efficiency by
fish control is thus secured.

Page 20: (31)-- This is very true. What you say of shallow edges--
which, indeed, generally obtain--is true for all kind of Anopheles: The
pollution by chemicals, so far as I have observed, applies only to A. cru-
cians, which will breed in water too acid for fish. I do not think that
A. quadrimaculatus or A. punctipennis will.

Page 20: (32)-- Some fish (as Gambusia and Fundulus) will work into a
fairly dense growth of vegetation or floatage and give a good percentage
of control. Much depends on the nature of the vegetation: Plants with
single, stiff stems at the water's surface offer little obstruction to fish
control--unless they be extremely close together (like a bunch of bulrushes).
Plants with flexible stems much longer than the depth of the water, the
tops of which float on, or just under, the surface as a dense mat, may
give absolute protection. The worst that I have seen is the wild celery
(Vallisneria spiralis) as it occurs in some bights of the Potomac, and
Naialis flexibilis in ponds in North Alabama is also bad. The ordinary water-lily rarely
gives much protection: while the dying pads of the American lotus hold
water in the cavity of their upper surface like boats and thus protect
larvae.
The Silnuleaf gross Hydrochloa carolin in Ponds in Georgia and South
South
-7-
Carolina is also bad, but less so than these two. The Burr Reed, Sparganium Americanus found
near Birmingham, Ala. and in the S. W. part of Virginia (east of the Blue
Ridge) spite of its stiff straight stems, is very bad for a short time. The seed--much like those of
the wild garlic--fall in the water in September & October and spread out as a float-
ing mucilaginous mass, catching all kinds of small floatage and specks of
alga, which grow well on it, and furnishes a perfect protection for larvae
against fish.

Page 20: (33)-- My experience has been that the breeding in the tracks
of the cattle about the edges of the pond much overbalances the good they
do in keeping vegetation down about the edges of the pond and, naturally,
they have no effect on the trash on the pond, which also protects larvae.
On the Canal Zone they were (and are now) regarded as doing only harm.
Page 20: (34)-- All of this is extremely good.

Page 20: (35)--Were these Anopheles larvae? They (A. larvae) are
usually killed directly by the contact with the oil, not by drowning.
Stegomyia larvae will live in cheese-cloth bags over 24 hours under water.
I have tried them.

I agree that really efficient oiling is frequently difficult, and at
times well nigh impossible. It is at best a temporary thing--a make-shift.
Against Anopheles. Paris green is very much better? Cheaper & more generally efficacious

Page 21: (36)-- Once in 12 or 14 days is generally often enough to
apply oil--whether there is wind or rain--if it be thoroughly done. If
thus applied, it will kill all eggs: larvae and pupae and while it may be
gone entirely within 4 or 6 hours and the place may show breeding again
within a few days, yet there will be no production of imagos for--say--
14 to 16 days. The aquatic forms of Anopheles do no harm. We do not try to prevent
breeding, only the production of the winged insect.

Page 21: (37)-- I doubt if the size of the pond is an absolute deterrent.
Saw good results on the Wateree Pond (S. C.) of, I think, 8,000 acres.

Page 21: (38)-- Even if some larvae escape, we may thus get a good per-
per-
-8-
centage of control--say 80% to 90%.

Page 21: (39)-- Not only vegetation (in which, I presume, algae are in-
cluded) but “floatage” on the pond as well, must be cared for.

Page 21: (40)--For Anopheles control, yes, top-feeders by all means: for
Stegomyia control--probably not.
Page 21: (41)-- As true as Gospel.
End.
H. R. Carter
